conclusion: Radar emits radio waves every 100 microseconds, each emission lasts for 1 microsecond.
The fluorescent screen shows three distinct peaks labeled as a, b, and c.
ab = bc implies distances between peaks a and b, and b and c are equal.
Time difference between each peak is the same, let it be T.
Time difference T corresponds to round-trip travel time of radio waves.
One-way travel time t is T/2.
Speed of light c in vacuum is 3.0 x 10^8 m/s.
Distance d to obstacle is calculated using d = c x t = c x (T/2).
Interval between emissions is 100 microseconds, T must be an integer multiple of this interval.
Since ab = bc, peaks correspond to successive reflections off the same obstacle, implying T = 100 microseconds.
Substitute T = 100 microseconds into distance formula: T = 100 x 10^-6 s = 10^-4 s.
Calculate d = c x t = 3.0 x 10^8 m/s x 5 x 10^-5 s = 1.5 x 10^4 m = 15 km.
The distance between the obstacle and the radar is 15 km.
